description: Vampire numbers (definition 2): numbers n with an even number of digits which have a factorization n = i*j where length(i) = length(j) = length(n)/2 and the multiset of the digits of n coincides with the multiset of the digits of i and j.
comments: The numbers i and j may not both have trailing zeros. Numbers may have more than one such factorization. However, each n is listed only once. [Comment modified by _Rick L. Shepherd_, Nov 02 2009]
references: C. A. Pickover, "Vampire Numbers." Ch. 30 in Keys to Infinity. New York: Wiley, pp. 227-231, 1995.
links: R. J. Mathar and Manfred Scheucher, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1006 (first 87 terms by R. J. Mathar)
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Vampire Number.
maple: n := 1 :for dgs from 4 to 10 by 2 do    for a from 10^(dgs-1) to 10^dgs-1 do        amset := sort(convert(a,base,10)) ;        isv := false ;        for d in numtheory[divisors](a) do            m := a/d ;            if ( m >= d ) then                dset := convert(d,base,10) ;                mset := convert(m,base,10) ;                fset := sort([op(dset),op(mset)]) ;                if fset = amset and nops(dset) = nops(mset) then                    if (m mod 10 <> 0 ) or (d mod 10 <> 0 ) then                    printf("%d %d\n",n,a) ;                    isv := true ;                    n := n+1 ;                    end if;                end if;            end if;            if isv then                break;            end if;        end do:    end do:end do: # _R. J. Mathar_, Jan 10 2013
crossrefs: The following sequences are all closely related: A020342, A014575, A080718, A048936, A144563.
author: _Eric W. Weisstein_
extensions: Edited by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jan 03 2009
